Stationeers is, next to Kerbal Space Program and Satisfactory, one of my favorite games of all times. It is probably the closest a game can get to offering true, (somewhat) realistic engineering challenges based on (simplified) physics simulations.

The game takes place on a planet or moon of choice, each of which have different environmental challenges. The player is deployed to the planet using a drop pod carrying a small set of supplies and finds themself in a rather desolate procedurally generated, voxel based landscape. Immediately, the clock starts to run; Your oxygen and the battery in your space suit will not last that long, so gathering resources and setting up an elementary life support systems is essential.

It becomes painfully clear that Stationeers fully deserves to be called a "survival" game. Unless you're following a detailed guide, failing and dying is almost completely inevitable the first few times you play.

Stationeers is a difficult game with a very steep learning curve. However, part of this is remedied by the excellent in-game documentation of all parts and materials.

Where most other similarly themed games go for a more abstracted, macro approach to things such as life support systems, Stationeers forces you to dive right into the nitty-gritty details of things. There is very little hand-holding as to how things are supposed to be put together. Instead, an impressive array of low-level components can be printed and used to build your own systems.

Automation is done by designing logic circuits or even using MIPS programming and IC chips. This is by far the most immersive way to include scripting/programming into a game that I have ever seen. As a software engineer by trade, this is one of my favorite aspects of the game.

The depth and complexity of Stationeers is truly staggering. For this reason the game also has a very steep learning curve; Something that tends to scare away new players, but this depth is undoubtedly reason for the game's very loyal fan base.

The development process of this early access game has not always been smooth sailing; Technical limitations have gotten in the way of promised and sometimes half-implemented features at times, especially during the early development phase. This has lead to features being removed and the scope of the game getting reduced.

Originally this game was clearly envisioned as Dean Hall's vision of what Space Engineers could/should have been. This is evident from early design choices and envisioned scope of the game. Earlier version had both static and movable grids, and many pieces meant to build flyable spacecrafts as well as rovers and static bases. However, technical design aspects of the engine that is used for the game made some of these features non-viable.

Instead of stubbornly chasing the original design goals, the team behind Stationeers has never been afraid to scap non-working concepts (like spacecraft, rovers, etc), and instead to focus on adding enormous depth to the well-working parts, namely base/station building and designing, building and automating advanced life-support systems using in-situ resource utilization. In these aspect, Stationeers far surpasses its source of inspiration.

While development of the game has felt stagnated in the past, I'm very happy to say that now in 2024, 7 years after the original early access release, development has noticable picked up again. Updates are being released at a steady pace. It is clear that the team listens to what the community wants and at the same time stays true to core principles that make the game great, even when they are widely critisized and challenged.

Probably one of the few simulation games that makes science fun. This is basically a game where you have to survive the elements and build the most sustainable base. Sounds simple, but it's very complex. You have to battle atmospheric conditions such as gravity, pressure, and temperature as they all play a pivotal role on not only your Stationeer but also your base. 

Storms such as blizzards on the Europa planet will send temperatures plummeting and fierce winds your way. If you're not already hunkered down in a pressurized base that has temperature control and backup power, you will be swept away in the icy cold winds never to see your base again. The temperatures will quickly drain your battery reserves, and inflict penalties on your suits o2 system. Rooms that are not insulated will be imposed by these real life thermodynamic conditions.

This game is great for a hardcore science enthusiast with a keen interest in space. But be forewarned, there is a huge learning curve to this game and tutorials are disabled. You can play outdated tutorials by reverting the game to a previous version in steam, but cycling between the two versions forces a 633MB download regardless if you've downloaded these versions before. So ultimately, you're reliant on youtube tutorials and a lot of trial and error. Your first 10-20 hours will be a bit of a struggle as your brain learns to adapt to the games punishing inventory control system and other mechanics.

I stopped playing as I got burnt out after 2 days of long sessions. Again, you're building a base and trying to survive to reach an end goal of building a rocket. There are features of the game that have been disabled or are not finished, like rover vehicles for example. They were causing issues in the game so they've been disabled for who knows how long. Nuclear power isn't a thing yet, despite being able to mine Uranium it doesn't really suit a purpose. Your characters have emotions but their facial reactions are disabled in the game settings, you might become attached to your character and want this. 

All in all, I think this game has great long term potential. Could it survive in development as long as Space Engineers has? I'm not sure. I would hope so, and that the game doesn't become abandoned. There really isn't quite any other games that come as close to this.

A few things that could be improved upon are the inventory management control and in game guides. The inventory management control is very fatiguing and constantly disrupts your ability to become "situated". The in game guides are kind of useless, I mostly used them to see what material / item requirements are and what recipes I needed in smelting. Tentative recommend.  There are large issues that will get in the way of enjoying this game, however there's nothing quite like it.
If you decide to get the game, note the pause icon in the in game documentation ( F1 ) if you plan to use it for a while.  You're on a timer, especially at the start, and you don't want to run out of oxygen looking up how to build an airlock.

Summary
The first phase of the game has you in survival mode, where you're running around trying to keep your suit powered and your character fed, all while scrounging for the materials you need to start building up your stockpiles of water, oxygen, food, and power while trying not to burn, freeze, or explode.

The second phase puts you in engineering mode, where you setup cryogenics for compressing gas for storage and liquid fuels, using logic to automate farming, solar panel tracking, or topping up your fuel mix.  Once you inevitably slip up your MIPS or logic settings the game throws you back into survival mode where you need to patch the massive hole that used to be your fuel storage put out the fires in your base.

The secret boss of the hidden third phase is, of course, learning and (mis)applying MIPS, the less understandable cousin of FORTRANs that offers less job prospects.  Hope you like branch statements and managing registers

Cons
Optimization leaves a bit to be desired, but I think most should be able to play it without slowdowns.  If you play on a world with storms you can expect your GPU to periodically act as a space heater.

Inventory management is terrible, scroll wheel to cycle which slot you're targetting, or hold alt while drag/dropping.  Opening or closing anything with an inventory will randomly shift which slot and/or inventory you are targetting, making it so you have to hunt your selector down again.

Documentation is terrible.  Mechanics are frequently undocumented, or the documentation is painfully out of date.  This goes for n-game help, the official wiki, and since mechanics tend to be tweaked after the initial release, player made guides as well.

In addition to lack of documentation and existing documentation becoming outdated as mechanics are expanded and changed, there are no tutorials any more.  There used to be, but they broke years ago and haven't been prioritized.  The studio's attitude appears to be to focus on mechanics and let the players figure it out and share among themselves.  Sometimes they'll drop in with clarification on their discord  with information that'll never be added into the in game wiki. You'll need to sleuth through discord for up to date information, but on the other hand the game is still being developed and I have enjoyed the additional complexity and mechanics that have been added over the years.


Pros
The game's decent looking, usually.  You don't have too many options for aesthetics when it comes to functional objects like walls and frames, but what's there can be made to look pretty nice.  Everything casts shadows against your lights, and while sometimes the pitch black shadows at night can be annoying it looks great and you can always add more lights assuming you can power them.  The worlds themselves are bit dull but it's not worldneers.  Most outside interaction can be automated away with various miners.

It is surprisingly immersive.  The inventory management embodies the feeling of juggling a bunch of tools and parts while you assemble your space-IKEA appliances.  A lot of items present their information on in game screens like tablets and laptops you keep in your hands or computers and consoles you place in the world.  [i]Most[/i] of the time the absence of quality of life features actually help encourage you to play it as a problem solving game.  Inventory management's still awful though.

The game tends to give you multiple ways to handle challenges, each with their own benefits and trade offs. 
 On top of that your choice of world will change how viable each option becomes.  You can manually mine materials, but probably not on Venus if you want to live.  Dig into bedrock for a random ore mix, but will be missing the gas and ices you could get if you're on a vacuum planet.  Setup and periodically shuffle strip miners, send rockets into space to gather ore and ice from asteroids, or call down traders and exchange renewables for them.  For power you have static solar panels and dynamic solar tracking, wind power if there's an atmosphere, coal or renewable charcoal generators, gaseous fuel generators, turbines to take advantage of pressure changes, and sterling engines to take advantage of temperature changes.

Almost every aspect have these tiny annoyances that add up to encourage more and more automation and problem solving.  The first you'll probably run into are with sheets, you need a lot for walls and frames but the autolathe's slow and spits them out into the world one at a time.  If it outputs more than a couple they'll start to get thrown everywhere as they run out of room.  Make two stackers, first to split off a set amount of steel, then another to stack the autolathe's output, suddenly you can just start it and come back to a full stack.  You can go even further by using logic and dials to stop it automatically instead of measuring metals, have it send everything to a vending machine, or even set it up to automatically keep a minimum stock of common items like pipes and walls.

Long-term goals include things like air filtration systems for your base, where you will need to figure out how to set up a network of vents, filters, wires and pipes (thankfully you can colour and label them though!) to keep your air breathable.

[h1] Is this similar to...[/h1]

[b][u] Space Engineers? [/u][/b]
The building and systems are more complex than Space Engineers. A good comparison is thrusters. In Space Engineers, you can put a thruster on blocks, add power and you're pretty much good to go. In this game, you're installing the fuel pipelines and mixtures going to the thrusters.

If Minecraft mod packs like Beastcraft or tekkit and the challenge of building complex processes appeal to you, you will probably like Stationeers. [b][u] Space Station 13? [/u][/b]
The game is heavily inspired by Space Station 13 mechanics, and many of the early testers were from the SS13 community. There is no rounds or similar though, and currently the game is entirely co-operative. Does not have clowns (yet).

[b][u] Astroneer? [/u][/b]
It may have a similar aesthetic, but they are quite different in gameplay. Astroneer is fairly simple in its mechanics when compared to Stationeers, especially when it comes to base-building. Mathematics. Engineering. Chemistry. Physics. Biology. It all comes into play in one form or another. It’s problem solving and learning science at its best. IN SPACE. It even allows you to gain a better grasp on Celsius, Kelvin, and Pascal’s if these units were once foreign to you.

Not only does Stationeers allow you to be crazy creative with base building, but you have to do it in a way that both works and is practical, yet it still allows you plenty of freedom to create something that is beautiful and stunningly complex. The learning curve is harsh, this game is not for casuals. Things can catch fire, they can blow up, you can suffocate from lack of power or oxygen, or a rip in your suit…you can even get shot 100’s of meters away from a pipe bursting in your face, but the immense reward and pride you feel from successfully solving a problem, automating a system, or figuring out how to create elements which provide long term survival is unlike any other joy I’ve found from a game…..

At the time of writing this, I had noticed recent reviews for this game being mixed. The critical reviews for this game are missing a big piece to the puzzle, so hopefully [b]MY[/b] review can add some perspective to help others understand what this game actually is.

[h1]Developer History:[/h1]
To understand Stationeers, you have to understand the guy making it: Dean "Rocket" Hall. Rocket is the man behind the popular ARMA mod: DayZ. Rocket began developing the DayZ mod as a side-project while he was working for Bohemia Interactive, when suddenly it went viral. DayZ had so much momentum that Bohemia Interactive allowed Rocket to work on it full-time. Soon, more resources were added to the project and Bohemia began working towards taking the mod and building it into a stand-alone game. I was playing DayZ around the time that the stand-alone version was released. I distinctly remember some of the game's new content and mechanics had felt very familiar to a BYOND game called Space Station 13, which I have been playing on-and-off for years. As it turned out, Rocket was a huge Space Station 13 fan and he was actively playing SS13 when he wasn't working on DayZ. Not too long after that, Rocket left Bohemia Interactive to found his own development studio: RocketWerkz. When I first saw Stationeers on Steam, I knew right away what this game was: Rocket is trying to create a modern Space Station 13.

[h1]Space Station 13 (SS13):[/h1]
If you are trying to measure Stationeers, you have to measure it against Space Station 13. SS13 is a 2D top-down multiplayer roleplaying game that has been around since the early 2000's. It is a community-developed game which is free to play and still has a healthy player base, despite being built using the BYOND engine. BYOND is a horrible 2D game engine that was created with the goal of making multiplayer game development easy for every-day folk back in the early 2000's. As a game, SS13 boasts an incredible amount of depth and a lot of realism. The gameplay experience is unique and like nothing else out there. The only problem with SS13 is that it is stuck on a crappy and outdated game engine. Over the years many people have tried to do a Space Station 13 remake, but none of the projects ever panned out. Stationeers is Rocket's passion project to finally bring us the 3D Space Station 13 remake many eager fans (myself included) have all been hoping for.

Space Station 13 features a unique mode of play, and I can see it all over Rocket's roadmap for Stationeers. It is played in 30-60 minute long rounds which usually end when the surviving players call an escape shuttle to evacuate the station. When a round begins, all players are spawned into the game and assigned a job. There are a variety of jobs available and each job has different access levels, equipment, and responsibilities. Some examples would be: Janitor, Security Officer, Captain, Head of Personnel, Chef, Botanist, Quartermaster, Medical Doctor, Staff Assistant, etc.. Each round, a few players are selected to be antagonists and are given a special role with special goals. To mix things up, there are different types of antagonist roles and nobody knows who might be an antagonist or even what the antagonist might be for the given round. The whole game takes place on a realistic working space station. The game simulates electricity, atmospherics, and also includes a really cool medical system. Most of the jobs have a staggering amount of depth and it can take hours of gameplay to master some of them.

[h1]Here is my point:[/h1]
Stationeers may seem like a space building / survival game, but it is likely to evolve into something that can also be played like Space Station 13. Instead of building a space station from the ground up, imagine spawning in the hydroponics lab of a fully-constructed realistic working space station as a botanist. While working on growing a hybrid tomato plant that has medicinal properties, you are blown across the room by a sudden explosion and are badly wounded. Stationeers is a game where you are required to construct, manage, monitor, and engineer your way through many survival obstacles on other worlds or in space. The game features a variety of planets to survive on and provides for hours upon hours of entertainment. That said, it's a niche game and it's difficult. If you are the person who jumps away from games at the drop of a hat because it's too confusing, difficult, or there's a lot of buzzing and whirring going on, look elsewhere. But, if you enjoy getting blown up, lost, frustrated, and then finally being met with success due to your engineering prowess, then this game might be for you. It's certainly a game I have enjoyed for hundreds of hours, but there is a lot of room for improvement and while some of that is expected for early access, read on to find out why I don't recommend this game overall.

I chose not to recommend the game because of the following three major reasons:
- Basic features which are apparently available through menu interactions do not work. This includes basic elements like tutorials, which do not properly work. It would be acceptable not to have tutorials yet, since the game is still in early access, but offering broken ones isn't good because it disrespects the players' time.

- Simple bugs exist in the game which cause loss of time. If you quick save from the menu, it works fine, but if you try to exit and click save when it reminds you to save, it removes data from your save and can render the world you've worked on completely unplayable with no option for recovery unless you want to dig into the files, folders, to rename and replace them while hoping it all works out.

- The game features a seemingly vast landscape which generates more terrain as you explore further. However, there is no reason to venture out except for introducing distance between locations you desire to build. That wouldn't be so bad, but if you venture just a few km from where you start, physics starts to break and you end up clipping through walls when you get too close. It just becomes a tease and then a letdown, essentially, with more wasted time the first time you discover these problems.

Seeing a theme yet? A fair number of bugs exist today which could waste the new player's time and require them to venture into Discord servers, unofficial wikis which are not up to date, and find workarounds on their own or with others. While that wouldn't normally be such a big deal, the Discord community lately has been unfairly and rudely judging negative reviews, newcomers asking questions or complaining about bugs, and there has been an increase in argumentative discussion when it involves representatives of the community (community contributor, community dev, etc) to the point someone was accused of spreading misinformation for stating a plain fact about how reorienting a daylight sensor will require an offset to be calculated in solar tracking automation.

To wrap this review up, I want to say it wasn't always this low in quality and in the past the game had very little performance issues for me. That means this low quality phase is probably something which will go just as quickly as it came and we'll be in a happy place again. Take this with a grain of salt, things change constantly

Only allow building straight/curved cables, make sure the player has enough cables with them, and then allow them to connect a cable they're running up to a point with another cable by just constructing another straight/curved cable on top of an existing one. While there are satisfying elements to this game, it fails to deliver an overall softcore intellectual experience. The atmospheric system is "the" complex system, which has obvious and unnecessary shortcomings. With so much attention given to temperature and pressure mechanics, somehow they managed to miss some of the most basic concepts like while heat increases pressure, pressure increases should also generate heat, but don't. The same is true of the inverse. The game decreases pressure when you cool a gas, but forgets that simply decreasing pressure and allowing gas to expand should also provide a cooling effect.  The first one is the key principal of how diesel engines work the second is the foundational concept of refrigeration and air conditioning. 

Every other system in the game is waved away from elementary school level questions with magic. 

 Power is reduced to just a simple wattage calculation: watts produced - watts consumed. The only depth offered is in the max wattage a cable can carry. What makes this sad is that the real calculation isn't that complex. Its the most basic algebra equation you can make with multiplication and division. Its a two term solve for X equation using  Voltage, Amperage, and Resistance. We don't even need to complicate it with Current types. DC power is all that is needed as the whole purpose behind AC power is for transmission over a long distance.   Watts, under and overloads, as well as  heat transfer to atmosphere from power consumption can be derived from the basic power equation, trivially. 

Considerations to planet composition are an instant face palm.  You land on an Ice moon ( a Water Ice Moon), and the terrain is not actually Ice. It's just voxel "soil" and you have to search for water Ice as mineral deposits.  Or you can land on Mars but can't process the soil or rock for resources. Instead, we have this ultra visible shiny node system that spawns pure elements. Most of them require an active hydro-logical system to produce.  Humanity hasn't relied on this type of visibly pure ore's for more than a couple hundred of years. Yeah we look for red to indicate Iron, but we don't look for shiny iron metal in the ground.  Even so, the Chemistry level is nonsensical and only gets a few basic things correct directly applied to human life support and only then at standard sea level pressures. No Nitrogen narcosis at high pressure or the need for pure Oxygen at low pressures. 

The developers added a DLC Alien character that should immediately detonate when it breathes because it breathes-in one element then exhales two completely different elements. In order for that to happen it's lungs have to be a Nuclear Fusion generator as hot as the core of a star going supernova.  Boom! They didn't even have to add any other gasses to make it work. It could have been as simple as it breathes in Hydrogen and exhales Water,  a chemical that at least contains one common element. Or it breathes in Nitros Oxide and exhales pure Nitrogen. Both situations keeping the desired incompatibility with Human requirements. They even could have made the Aliens breathe Hydrocarbons (C, H, and O), making co-habitation with a human as dangerous as routing the exhaust from a car into the passenger compartment.   

Absolutely everything we know about what the actual survival requirements will be on other planets is Chemistry based. To have that glossed over is insulting.  To have it glossed over, while providing much more difficult to balance and operate atmospheric systems, plus needing programming for end game content,  is cognitively dissonant. 

The most telling design failure of predicting the intelligence level of it's player base, is that the most common questions everyone asks are "Why is there Coal, a fossil Fuel, on places with no fossils or life?" and "How is there solid Oxygen, Hydrogen, and Water Ice on planets that can melt my space suit or have molten lava exposed every few feet?" 

Having said all of that, the lack of anything better, still makes this the best option for technical immersion out there, but then its bound to be as limiting as having only one politician run in a political race.
